A couple of FYIs:

  1. All Code-School courses are free this weekend. They have a really good course on JS Objects, Arrays, Maps, Sets ...etc (https://www.codeschool.com/courses/es2015-the-shape-of-javascript-to-come). I highly recommend taking advantage of the free-weekend to plow through their JS courses.
@pmbenjamin I'm going to head over to MDN and check out maps then.
@pmbenjamin I see.

@pmbenjamin I imagine I'd structure it like this
```
'use strict'
let drawer = {}
drawer.hundreds = new Object()
drawer.hundreds.amount = 200
drawer.hundreds.slotnumber = 1

console.log(drawer.hundreds.amount) // 200
```

i can't think of a use-case off the top of my head, but it is a common pitfall that new JavaScript developers fall in when they try to treat objects as maps. I think the purpose of the exercise in question is not really "best practice", but rather to get you used to retrieving values from 2D arrays. That's all.
@BenjaminDowns what if you want to get the slot number and the dollar amount from the drawer?

@BenjaminDowns 
If you use dot notation, you're no longer trying to add the content of your variable to the object. Instead, you're literally adding a new key.
For instance, if `hundreds = {slot: 5, name: "hundreds"}` and you try to assign the content of `hundreds` variable to `drawer` object like so `drawer.hundreds = 200` expecting to get `drawer = { {slot: 5, name: "hundreds"}: 200}`, you will instead get `drawer = {hundreds: 200}`
You can try it in https://repl.it/BtOR.
It doesn't have to do with how you add keys to objects, it has to do with the JavaScript behavior under the hood.
(by the way, I'm being stubborn not for the sake of obstinacy itself; I just want to understand a bit more.)
why not just  ```drawer.hundreds = 200``` ?
@pmbenjamin Ah. I see. And if we use dot notation?

@pmbenjamin Right, I know; but surely key/value pairs, even if the key is a string, is going to be more intuitive than a 2D array! 
For instance:

```

let drawer = {
  'hundreds': 200,
  'twenties': 40,
  'tens': 20
}
drawer['hundreds'] // 200; NOTE: no need to remember index numbers, since we have keys

```
as opposed to:

```
drawer = [['hundreds', 200], ['twenties', 40], ['tens', 20]]

//

drawer[0][1] // 200 ; have to use index numbers to select both the proper denomination, [0] and the value[1]

```

@BenjaminDowns there are subtleties and unexpected pitfalls in JavaScript objects that you have to be aware of.
**TL;DR** JavaScript Objects can't be used as key/value-pair maps.
**Long Explanation:**
JavaScript always converts Object Keys (e.g. `HUNDREDS`) to strings (e.g. `"HUNDREDS"`).

Let's take a look at an example:
```javascript
var user1 = {name: "John"}; // user1 object
var user2 = {name: "Ben"}; // user2 object

var totalMoney = {}; //Object to store how much money each user has
totalMoney[user1] = 1;
totalMoney[user2] = 500;

// What happens when you print their values out?
console.log(totalMoney[user1]); // => 500
console.log(totalMoney[user2]); // => 500
```
You see, JavaScript converted `user1` and `user2` keys to `"[object Object]"`.
This was resolved in ES2015 (aka ES6) with the introduction of `Map` data structure.
You can get away with using JS Objects as maps **if, and only if,** you are building the Object as an Object Literal (e.g. `var someObj = {key1: value1, key2: value2};`).
Besides, don't let JavaScript Arrays fool you, they're JavaScript Objects under the hood.

Breaking out the 3rdtest case:
```
assert.deepEqual(where([{ 'a': 1, 'b': 2 }, { 'a': 1 }, { 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 2 }], { 'a': 1, 'b': 2 }), [{ 'a': 1, 'b': 2 }, { 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 2 }], 'should return two objects in array');
```
Breaking it out:
```
where(
[{ 'a': 1, 'b': 2 }, { 'a': 1 }, { 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 2 }], // First Param (Collection)
{ 'a': 1, 'b': 2 });  // Second Param (source)
// Results:
[{ 'a': 1, 'b': 2 }, { 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 2 }]  // Returns these two objects
```

I previously deveopmed on LAMP stack and seeding was super dangerous bozo-no-no
Since the seeds all have an ID, only those records get overwritten.
But if you're using MongoDB, it's totally a normal thing to do.  IT's quasi less destructive.
@CharlesMilam Well, if you come from an SQL background, it's like sacralige, right?
Gotya. Reseeding the whole database for just a single fix, just doesn't feel right, but what do I know ;-)
Bad syntax on the tests can break the whole page and/or truncate the seed data upload.  That's bad ;)
And the syntax is a bit weird since you're writing code encapsulated in a string.
I suppose . . . but you need to also test that you've made the changes to the .json file correctly.  An invalid json file cannot be loaded when they deploy your fix.
Ok, or I guess in theory you could just do an update for that specific document (i.e. record in a rdbms), so you wouldn't have to reseed the whole database, correct?
@CharlesMilam They're just "in" the seed files for re-loading.
@CharlesMilam The challenges are stored in the database.
@CharlesMilam Yes, you edit the appropriate .json file and then re-seed (via `node seed`)
